site_name: NAVAJO NATION ZOO AND BOTAN PK

citations.narrative:
Two outdoor enclosures for birds do not have adequate shelter to protect the animals housed therein from all weather
conditions. One outdoor enclosure has 2 Domestic Turkeys, 2 Sandhill Cranes, 2 Domestic Chickens, 2 Turkey Vultures,
and 2 Peafowl. Another outdoor enclosure has 2 Swainson's Hawks, 5 Red-tailed Hawks and 1 Ferruginous Hawk. Both
enclosures have trees and vegetation that provide shade and relief from sun exposure, but there is not shelter that can
protect against other climatic elements such as wind and precipitation for all animals. Outdoor housing facilities must
provide adequate shelter, appropriate to the species and physical condition of the birds, for the local climatic conditions to
protect the birds from any adverse weather conditions. Shelters must be adequately ventilated in hot weather and have
one or more separate areas of shade or other effective protection that is large enough to comfortably contain all the bird
at one time and prevent their discomfort from direct sunlight, precipitation, or wind.
Correct by 20 September 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility does not have a developed and documented avian environment enhancement plan. Failure to develop,
document and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement of regulated birds may result in their poor
psychological welfare. Exhibitors must develop, document and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment
enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the attending
veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in this subpart.
Correct by 5 August 2024.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The facility representative stated that only water is used to clean the hard surfaces and water and food receptacles in the
outdoor enclosure housing 18 Golden Eagles. The animals are fed a raw meat and whole prey diet. No accumulation of
food waste or excreta was observed in the primary enclosure during inspection and the water receptacle had no debris
present. Failure to properly clean and sanitize hard surfaces of the primary enclosure of birds and their food and water
receptacles may result in illness or injury to the animals. Primary enclosures and food and water receptacles for birds
must be sanitized as often as necessary to prevent accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease
hazards.
Correct by 5 August 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.152(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor 
Two outdoor enclosures for birds do not have adequate shelter to protect the animals housed therein from all weather 
conditions. One outdoor enclosure has 2 Domestic Turkeys, 2 Sandhill Cranes, 2 Domestic Chickens, 2 Turkey Vultures, 
and 2 Peafowl. Another outdoor enclosure has 2 Swainson's Hawks, 5 Red-tailed Hawks and 1 Ferruginous Hawk. Both 
enclosures have trees and vegetation that provide shade and relief from sun exposure, but there is not shelter that can 
protect against other climatic elements such as wind and precipitation for all animals. Outdoor housing facilities must 
provide adequate shelter, appropriate to the species and physical condition of the birds, for the local climatic conditions to 
protect the birds from any adverse weather conditions. Shelters must be adequately ventilated in hot weather and have 
one or more separate areas of shade or other effective protection that is large enough to comfortably contain all the bird 
at one time and prevent their discomfort from direct sunlight, precipitation, or wind.  
 
Correct by 20 September 2024. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility does not have a developed and documented avian environment enhancement plan. Failure to develop, 
document and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement of regulated birds may result in their poor 
psychological welfare. Exhibitors must develop, document and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment 
enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the attending 
veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in this subpart. 
 
Correct by 5 August 2024. 
3.158(b)(1) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The facility representative stated that only water is used to clean the hard surfaces and water and food receptacles in the 
outdoor enclosure housing 18 Golden Eagles. The animals are fed a raw meat and whole prey diet. No accumulation of 
food waste or excreta was observed in the primary enclosure during inspection and the water receptacle had no debris

present. Failure to properly clean and sanitize hard surfaces of the primary enclosure of birds and their food and water 
receptacles may result in illness or injury to the animals. Primary enclosures and food and water receptacles for birds 
must be sanitized as often as necessary to prevent accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease 
hazards.  
 
Correct by 5 August 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
